title: SSC Journal Club: Dissolving The Fermi Paradox
summary:
Key ideas:
- Fermi Paradox asks why we see no evidence of alien civilizations despite the vastness of the universe
- Drake Equation calculates the probability of alien civilizations existing
- SDO's synthetic point estimate model accounts for parameter uncertainty and yields a probability of one in three for the existence of alien civilizations in our galaxy
- "Alternative genetic systems" could hinder the development of complex life on other planets

Key learnings:
- Relying solely on the mean of a probability distribution can be misleading
- What we're interested in is the distribution of probability over the number of alien civilizations
- The Drake Equation may not take into account parameter uncertainty

Key questions:
- Should we be relying on the Drake Equation to calculate the probability of alien civilizations existing?
- What are "alternative genetic systems" and how could they impact the development of life on other planets?
- Why did it take so long for someone to realize that the mean of the probability distribution isn't enough to draw conclusions about alien life?
